comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The warship looks similar to the German Imperial Navy BUSSARD,  (but it isn't!) - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3229538689/]

comment.author: 66546790@N07
comment._content: The ship is the German cruiser Condor. In 1903-1913 she was serving in South Asia and often visited Sydney for repair (spring of 1905, 1907, 1908, 1912).

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66546790@N07] Thanks for identification of the Condor. A detailed Pacific itinerary of the ship is here, showing dates of arrival in numerous ports: marshall.csu.edu.au/Marshalls/html/history/Condor.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66546790@N07] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] That's great! SMS CONDOR (1892-1921) she is. Wikipedia - de.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMS_Condor (with photo) Full details - www.german-navy.de/hochseeflotte/ships/avisos/condor/inde... including - " ... the Kreuzer IV. Class of the Bussard class. Not build after the requirements of naval fleet battles, but specially designed ships for overseas duty. Beside their huge coal capacity, they were equipped with sails to assist the steam engines. Quite unusual for its time, the cruisers were equipped with an electrical system and a huge flashlight on top of the command bridge. ... " - not in evidence in this photo?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66546790@N07] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] Thanks Atoine R for the information, our records have been updated. Thanks also to beachcomber and AndyBrii for the links!
